ALLEGATION:
611 W. OTTAWA  P.O. BOX 30664  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909

Agency Staff witnessed two separate alleged assaults to a youth by a CCI staff
member while required to supervise youth. Agency Staff were aware of these
events minimally since 2/23/22 but failed to comply with CPL Mandated
reported policy. Alleged abuse/neglect was not reported for over a week after
one of the most recent assaults.
INVESTIGATION:
Reporting Source 1 and 2 basically reported the same information as in the
allegation. Their concerns were that an investigation was being conducted at a Child
Caring Institution regarding the possible assault of Youth A by the staff member who
was monitoring him at the hospital. The Reporting Sources stated the alleged
assaults occurred at the hospital on 2/23/24 and 2/24/2022. Agency Staff witnessed
the alleged assaults; however, the allegations were not reported to Central Intake
until almost a week later. The Agency Staff are mandated reporters and are required
to report allegations of abuse and/or neglect immediately to Central Intake.
I reviewed case notes in MiSACWIS written by Staff 1 on 2/24/2022, and Staff 1
provided clarification to the notes. The notations and clarifications are as follows:
 Upon arriving at McLaren Caro Hospital, Staff 1 walked into the building and
signed in right behind the staff member from a Child caring institution who was
responsible for monitoring Youth A during the shift. Staff 1 spoke to the Child
caring institution staff that was being relieved and the staff member provided
Staff 1 with an update on Youth A. The staff member from Child caring
institution reported that Youth A slept through the night but woke up in an
irritated state. Staff 1 said she witnessed Youth A pushing against the Child
caring institution staff that was being relieved and was trying to get into the
hallway. Staff 1 said Youth A attempted to punch the Child caring institution
staff who reported on duty to monitor him. The Child caring institution staff put
knee pads on and immediately threw Youth A onto the floor of the hospital
room and scolded Youth A not to punch staff. Child caring institution staff
continued to restrain Youth A and Youth A’s behaviors continued to escalate.
Staff 1 said five nurses came into the room to hold Youth A down while the
Child caring institution staff and nurses put Youth A in restraints on his legs
and arms.
Youth A fought and started to spit at the nurses and staff member faces. A
sheet was put over Youth A’s face to prevent him from spitting on the nurses
and staff. Youth A was given an injection in his back side, Staff 1 said she
assumed it was to calm Youth A down. Staff 1 said Youth A was able to
remove his restraints within minutes and continued to do so for about ½ hour,
while the nursing staff continued to put them back on.
 Staff 1 reported Youth A eventually calmed down and asked to eat his
breakfast, around 8:45a.m. Restraints were taken off, he drank apple juice, ate
a pancake, sausage, and toast. After breakfast, Child caring institution staff
611 W. OTTAWA  P.O. BOX 30664  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov/lara  517-335-1980

member attempted to read a book to Youth A. He listened for a while but was
easily distracted. At one point, a nurse stated that Youth A had not taken his
medications from last night or that morning.
 Staff 1 said Youth A was pleasant and asked to play on Staff 1’s phone. A
non-violent game was downloaded, and a ten-minute timer was set. When the
timer went off, Youth A let Staff 1 know. Staff 1 allowed Youth A to keep the
phone and look for an appropriate movie to watch. He was told by Child caring
institution staff member that he could not watch Walking Dead or anything but
PG movies. Youth A attempted a few minutes to watch an appropriate movie
and gave the phone back to Staff 1.
 About 9:30 a.m., Staff 1 asked if there was anything Youth A could or would
like to do, because he had been doing well. Youth A stated that he wanted to
take a walk, so Staff 1 and Youth A went to the nurses’ station to ask. The
nurse agreed that he could take a walk as long as someone was with him.
Staff 1, Youth A, and the Child caring institution staff member proceeded to
take a walk around the hospital floor. Youth A was redirected several times
from going into rooms. A hospital staff member opened the cafeteria so Youth
A could go in and have a drink of pop. Youth A had a pleasant conversation
with cafeteria staff and asked for shrimp, then asked for several other things
and wanted a snack. The cafeteria staff was unable to give Youth A anything
but talked about what she was able to make for lunch and dinner. Staff 1 then
directed Youth A out of the cafeteria. Youth A stated he wanted a snack and
stopped at the vending machines to pick out what he would like. Staff 1 told
Youth A that if he behaved, she would buy him a snack when he returned to
his room. Youth A tried to go to the gift shop, which was not open, and asked
several hospital staff members to open it for him. He was then directed back
towards his room. Youth A went into the physical therapy room and refused to
leave, stating he was allowed in that room. When Staff 1 tried to direct Youth A
out of the room, he started to escalate. Child caring institution Staff member
aggressively pulled Youth A towards the door; Youth A fell to the ground. Child
caring institution staff member and a male nurse then dragged Youth A on the
floor back to his room. Youth A then escalated further, got away from staff and
locked himself in the bathroom. Youth A then proceeded to break the paper
towel dispenser, squirt conditioner all over the ceiling, walls and mirror and
throw whatever he could around the bathroom. Hospital maintenance unlocked
the door with a screwdriver.
 About 10:30 a.m., during the incident described above Child caring institution
staff member grabbed Youth A and put him on the bed, while two nurses came
into the room to restrain him. Staff 1 grabbed the bag of restraints while Child
caring institution staff member held down Youth A’s legs and the nurses held
his upper half. Youth A was again restrained to the bed with 6 restraints. Two
for each arm and one on each ankle. Youth A complained of his ankles
hurting, so the male nurse checked his pulse in both ankles and made sure
611 W. OTTAWA  P.O. BOX 30664  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov/lara  517-335-1980

there was enough room. A female nurse gave Youth A another shot in the
arm. She was also scratched on the arm while holding Youth A down, she
cleaned herself and Youth A of blood, right after. Youth A started to calm down
and asked why his blood was so thick today. Child caring institution Staff
member explained that Youth A probably did not have enough water to drink
and was dehydrated. Staff 1 noticed that there was blood on the sheet under
Youth A’s arm and dried blood where he may have been given a shot
previously.
 About 11:00 a.m., Male nurse talked to Youth A at length, about his behaviors
and how he would not be allowed to take another walk that day. Youth A said
he understood and was calm now that the nurse had given him a “pep talk”
and wanted out of his restraints. The nurse explained that Youth A needed to
be in the restraints for an hour or until he was very calm. The nurse then asked
if Youth A would like his morning medicine and Youth A stated that he would.
When the nurse returned with two meds, Youth A attempted to negotiate for
his release from the restraints in return for taking the medication. There was
more talk and Youth A allowed the nurse to put the pills in his mouth and took
a drink of water.
 11:30 a.m., at this time, Staff 2, the next DHHS worker arrived and Staff 1
updated Staff 2 about the morning shift. Staff 1 left the hospital.
Interview Staff 1
I interviewed Staff 1 regarding this allegation. She reported basically what was in
her social work notes regarding the allegation. She added when the Child caring
institution staff member noticed that Youth A was escalated and punching at staff, the
staff immediately put his knee pads on and walked towards Youth A in an aggressive
stance. Staff 1 said the Child caring institution staff member explained to her that Youth
A had left their staff members, as well as nursing staff, bruised and he hurt his knees,
which is why he was wearing knee pads. Staff 1 said Youth A attempted to run out of
his bedroom and that the Child caring institution Staff member grabbed Youth A’s arm
and forcefully threw him back into the room onto the bed. Staff 1 made the observation
along with another staff that the Child caring institution staff was excessive and that the
staff seems to be protecting himself and others rather than Youth A. Staff 1 said she did
not report the information to Central Intake until a week later because she was waiting
for a meeting to discuss the incident with her manager and director. She said she
immediately discussed the incident with her supervisor. Staff 1 said she was unsure
about this incident and if it was child abuse because she lacked experience in child
caring institutions and restraints. Staff 1 said she also observed the hospital staff’s
involvement in the restraint, and she was usure if anything was wrong. Staff 1 said in
her opinion, Youth A was very aggressive and physical at times, but she felt that Child
caring institution staff was overly assertive and that his behaviors were unnecessary.
Staff 1 said she was unaware of the guidelines put in place for the safety of Youth A and
others, and this is why she discussed the incident with her supervisor.

Interview Staff 2
I interviewed Staff 2 regarding the allegation. She reported observing the Child caring
institution Staff member on 2/24/22 exhibit aggressive behaviors towards Youth A and
that she reported the information to her supervisor after her shift ended. Staff 2 said she
was not sure if the situation rose to abuse or not. Staff 2 said she did not witness the
staff member hit Youth A but rather held him down forcefully on the bed while restraints
were being applied to his legs and arms. She was concerned about the size
of Youth A compared to Child caring institution staff member. Staff 2 said a meeting
was held with the program manager and the director a week later regarding the incident.
She said she was informed to contact central intake 30 minutes later after the meeting.
Interview Licensing Supervisor
I interviewed the Licensing Supervisor regarding the allegation. She is the supervisor
of Staff 1 and Staff 2. The Licensing Supervisor reported she and the administration
were aware of the incident at the hospital on 02/24/2022, however, she was not
aware of anything occurring on the 23rd or another incident on another date. She
said Staff 1 and staff 2 (both licensing workers) only supervised Youth A once and
that was on the 24th. Both staff (both licensing workers) met with the Licensing
Supervisor the day after the incident that they were unsure how to categorize what
they saw. They described a very aggressive child, an aggressive Child caring institution
staff and hospital staff who participated in the restraints and gave the youth injections to
calm his behavior. Due to the concerns raised, a meeting was scheduled with upper
management.
The Licensing Worker reported at this meeting with upper management Staff 1 and 2,
were again asked to report what they saw. When asked if they felt the child was
being abused, both staff still said they felt what they saw was excessive but could
not say they felt it was abuse based on the child’s aggressive and sometimes
assaultive behavior and need to be restrained, sometimes by more than one
person. She said Staff 1 and 2 also didn’t know what the Child caring institution staff
member was instructed to do in a situation when a youth is totally out of control. It
was decided by upper administration that based on the description of what occurred
and the use of the word excessive by Staff 1 and 2, the lack of information about
how Child caring institution staff person was to perform his job, and the participation of
hospital staff that a report would be made to Central Intake. Staff 1 and 2 were
instructed to call Central Intake immediately. They complied with this directive and
direction from upper management.
DHHS policy for reporting to Central Registry
DHHS policy regarding reporting child abuse is that any suspicion of child abuse
should be reported to Central Intake. The policy states:
Staff are held to the standards set in the Mandated Reporter Training and information
in the online manuals for services workers. Department employee who is one of the
611 W. OTTAWA  P.O. BOX 30664  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov/lara  517-335-1980

following and suspects child abuse or neglect must make a report of suspected child
abuse or neglect to the department:
• Eligibility specialist.
• Family independence manager.
• Family independence specialist.
• Social services specialist.
• Social work specialist.
• Social work specialist manager.
• Welfare services specialist.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12214 Compliance with 1975 PA 238.
An agency shall develop a written plan and implement the plan
to assure compliance with 1975 PA 238, MCL 722.621, and
known as the child protection law.
ANALYSIS Staff 1 and Staff 2 are Licensing Workers who were assigned to
monitor Youth A during his stay at the psychiatric hospital, along
with Child caring institution staff member. Neither of the
Licensing Workers has experience with child caring institutions,
or restraints. They both viewed the restraint on Youth A as
possibly excessive based on Youth’s A’s size. Staff 1 seemed
puzzled about Child caring institution staff member wearing
knee pads. Staff 1 and 2 also observed hospital nursing staff
involved in the restraint of Youth A as well as giving Youth A
injections to calm him down. They did not describe Child caring
institution staff to be assaultive or to restrain Youth A without
provocation. Staff 1 nor Staff 2 reported that they suspected
child abuse, although both describe the handling of Youth A’s
behavior as excessive.
It is for that reason that Staff 1 and 2 sought guidance for their
supervisor who sought guidance from their upper administration.
After some discussion among the administrators, Staff 1 and
Staff 2 were told to contact Central Intake. The incident
occurred on February 24, 2022, and Central Intake was
contacted on March 3, 2022. Staff 1 and 2 did not suspect child
abuse. Their lack of experience with restraints and the
participation of the medical staff led to their confusion. They
sought the advice of their superiors who determined that it was
best to let Central Intake staff decide if this situation was child
abuse. Please note the behavior of Child caring institution staff
member is the subject of Special Investigation 2022C0137017.
611 W. OTTAWA  P.O. BOX 30664  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov/lara  517-335-1980

The Central Intake investigation will be conducted on the child
caring institution Despite confusion Staff 1 and 2 are mandated
reporters and should have reported it.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
I recommend that St. Clair County DHHS License remains unchanged, upon receipt
of an approved corrective action plan
